Award.AwardTitle: Advancing the Synthesis and Applications of Pyrrole-Modified Porphyrins
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, the research group led by Professor Christian Brueckner of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Connecticut will develop a number of dyes derived from the naturally occurring molecule class called porphyrins. This compound class gives blood (hemoglobin) its deep red color. Altering the molecular structure of the porphyrin slightly by insertion, replacement, or deletion of atoms at defined positions varies their optical properties. Thus, for example, dyes are derived that absorb a large portion of sunlight, making them attractive options for light-harvesting applications. Other dyes possess properties that may make them useful as contrast agents for optical imaging in medicine, a potentially notable broader scientific impact. The work begins with the development of the synthetic strategies to generate the novel dyes. Once prepared, their physical properties are evaluated. The strong interdisciplinary nature of the work provides excellent training for graduate and undergraduate students for a modern and inclusive workforce.

The main objective of this grant is the development of strategies to convert porphyrins into pyrrole-modified porphyrins (PMPs), macrocycles derived from porphyrins by formally replacing at least one pyrrolic building block with a different heterocycle. Starting from meso-arylporphyrins or octaethylporphyrin, a little explored but versatile strategy will be pursued: activation of the beta position of porphyrins, followed by ring cleavage and subsequent ring-fusion. This generates PMPs containing one or two five, six, and seven-membered non-pyrrolic heterocycles and that may also incorporate extended pi-systems through beta-to-meso-phenyl linkages. The guiding hypothesis of the work is that these modifications result in drastically altered electronic properties when compared to their parent porphyrins or chlorins. Particularly with respect to their longest wavelength of absorbance and fluorescence, their hyperchromic and, in some cases, panchromic spectra, and in their efficient non-radiative relaxation processes, many PMPs possess remarkable photophysical properties of potential utility. In collaboration with specialty groups, their application in select fields will be tested. Structure-physical properties relationships will also be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Porphyrins are large rings that are, for their importance in life events as light harvesters, oxygen transport, of enzyme action, are part of the so-called pigments of life. Pyrrole-modified porphyrins (PMPs) are porphyrins in which at least one of the pyrrolic building blocks is replaced by a non-pyrrolic heterocycle. Over the last decade, we prepared a wide range of structurally diverse PMPs (Scheme 1) by conversion of a porphyrin using our porphyrin breaking and mending strategy (Scheme 2). Over the period of the current grant proposal, the intellectual merits of the proposal included that we expanded the examples of PMPs that could be made using this strategy, that we refined our understanding of the scopes − and particularly the limits − of this approach when it came to the generation of PMPs with larger than six-membered heterocycles or the establishment of two (or more) non-pyrrolic building blocks. 

We also investigated the physical properties of a range of PMPs and revealed their structural origin, whereby it is notable that many PMPs possess distinctly different physical properties from those of the parent porphyrins and chlorins: For example, some PMPs yield intense and much red-shifted (into the near-infra red portion of the electromagnetic spectrum), or panchromic (absorbing every wavelength from 300 to above 900 nm) optical spectra, some emit light above 1200 nm, while others quenched all fluorescence. The optical properties are a result of their connectivity but most often also of their chromophore conformation: While some were similarly planar as porphyrins, other proved to be non-planar, to expressed stable chiral helimeric conformations, or unusual conformational flexibility. In fact, fundamentally new conformational effects that control their electronic structure were discovered. Some PMP-metal complexes exhibited unique electrochemical properties or, in case of some PMP platinum complexes, better partial oxygen pressure-dependent luminescence profiles.

These properties are the basis for the potential applications, providing excellent structural leads for a number of technical and biomedical applications. Many PMPs carry functionalities at their macrocycle peripheries that are strongly coupled with their chromophores, suggesting their use as chemosensors. Indeed, we demonstrated that PMPs could operate as chemosensors for hydroxide, alkoxides, or cyanide. Particularly the hydroxide-sensing ability proved to be very useful for the structural health monitoring of building concrete. Some other applications of PMPs that utilize their intrinsic electronic structures, such as electro-catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction, carbon dioxide reduction, or photoacoustic contrast agents for the photoacoustic imaging (PAI) of breast tissue phantoms and tumors in mouse models, were also explored by us in more depth. Our work has been flanked by others who also probed the unique and useful properties of PMPs, in part taking advantage of the methodologies developed by us.

Thus, this proposal allowed us to address broadly both fundamental and applied aspects of PMP synthesis and properties. We learned about broader aspects like aromaticity or conformational electronic modulation of π-expanded systems, aspects influencing wider areas of chemistry. The interdisciplinary study of the PMPs had broad impacts on the training of a new generation of chemists and, in collaborative efforts, engineers. We expect select PMPs to be of further utility in a number of technical and biological applications, ultimately impacting a number of fields.
